speech.p: Tosnóimid an dara leath den chruinniú seo. As we are in public session, I wish to give witnesses and members a note on privilege. Witnesses who are giving evidence from within the parliamentary precincts in Leinster House are protected by absolute privilege in respect of the evidence they give to this committee. This means they have a full defence in any defamation action for anything said at the meeting. However, witnesses are expected not to abuse this privilege and may be directed by the Chair to cease giving evidence on any issue. Witnesses should follow the direction of the Chair in this regard and are reminded of the long-standing parliamentary practice to the effect that, as is reasonable, no adverse commentary should be made against an identifiable third person or entity. Witnesses who are to give evidence from a location outside the parliamentary precincts are asked to note that they may not benefit from the same level of immunity from legal proceedings as witnesses giving evidence from within the parliamentary precincts. They may consider it appropriate to take legal advice on this matter. Privilege against defamation does not apply to the publication by witnesses outside of the proceedings of this committee of any matters arising from the proceedings.

Members have already been reminded of their obligation to be physically present within the confines of the Leinster House complex and of the long-standing parliamentary practice that they should not criticise or make charges against any person or entity by name or in such a way as to make him, her or it identifiable or otherwise engage in speech that might be regarded as damaging to the good name of the person or entity.

Our agenda item is a discussion on capital and infrastructure related to the subject matter of this committee, which is fisheries and maritime affairs. The committee has already heard from a number of witnesses broadly categorised as harbour users. We have heard from several of the fisheries organisations and the RNLI.

For this meeting, we have a number of witnesses broadly representing the Department and the local authority or local government sector. I will go through the witnesses now and then I will ask them for two-minute summaries of their opening statements before we begin the question-and-answer session. We will go for seven minutes per member of the committee and that will include both the questions and the answers. That should allow us to get around the houses with all five members who are currently present to have our opportunity.

From the Department of Agriculture, Food and the Marine, we are joined by Ms Sinéad McSherry, assistant secretary general, Ms Eimear Coughlan, principal officer, and Mr. Noel Clancy, chief engineer; and from the County and City Management Association transport infrastructure and networks committee, we have Mr. Barry Kehoe, chair of the committee and chief executive of Westmeath County Council, Mr. Tom Prendergast, senior engineer at Galway County Council, and Mr. Cathal Sweeney, resident engineer at Donegal County Council.
I invite Ms McSherry or one of her colleagues to deliver a two-minute summary of the Department’s opening statement.

I thank the committee for the invitation to speak to it today. The Chairman has introduced us so I will not do that again. The Department of Agriculture, Food and the Marine owns, operates and maintains six designated State-owned fishery harbour centres, located at Castletownbere, Dingle, Dunmore East, Howth, Killybegs and Ros an Mhíl. We also have responsibility for North Harbour at Cape Clear Island, as well as the maintenance of a small number of specific piers, lights and beacons throughout Ireland. Investing in our marine infrastructure is particularly important to the resilience of our seafood sector. The Department, subject to project feasibility and the prioritisation of resources, administers the annual fishery harbour and coastal infrastructure development programme, consistent with the objectives of the NDP. The strategic objective of the programme is to contribute to, from an infrastructure perspective, the future viability of the fishing industry and the sustainability of our coastal communities.

Between January 2010 and December 2024, the Department has invested almost €356 million in publicly owned marine infrastructure through a mix of national Exchequer and Brexit adjustment reserve funding. The Department’s engineering division profiles a five- to seven-year capital work programme and prioritises those projects that will bring the infrastructure for which the Department has responsibility up to best international standards. Each year, the Department also carries out approximately 50 projects of various sizes. Some projects may be scheduled over a number of phases to take account of the available annual funding, competing national priorities and the capacity of the Department to deliver.

Since 2020, €138.5 million has been invested in capital works in the fishery harbour centres in Cape Clear, delivering projects such as the Dinish wharf expansion and breakwaters at Castletownbere, the middle pier at Howth and the Smooth Point pier extension at Killybegs. In March, the Minister of State, Deputy Dooley, announced a capital investment package of €23.4 million as part of the 2025 programme. The allocation included capital commitments for ongoing projects and the commencement of some new projects. In addition, the programme provided limited discretionary funding for small-scale shovel-ready development and the repair of local authority-owned harbours, piers and slipways subject to available Exchequer funding. This year, the Minister of State announced an allocation of €4.33 million for 57 projects across the 11 coastal local authorities. Between 2020 and 2024, the Department reimbursed total funding of almost €56 million under the local authority marine infrastructure and Brexit adjustment local authority marine infrastructure schemes.

It should be noted that the Department is not the responsible body for the development and maintenance of local authority-owned infrastructure. This lies in the first instance with the local authorities and with their parent Department, the Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage.
My colleagues and I will take any questions members may have in respect of the Department’s infrastructure.
I thank Ms McSherry. I now invite Mr. Kehoe or one of his colleagues to give a two-minute summary of their opening statement.

I thank the committee for the invitation to appear. Irish local authorities manage hundreds of piers, harbours and slipways and support local coastal economies. They are critical not only to our fishing industry but increasingly to tourism, aquaculture, marine leisure activities and the broader blue economy. The challenge we face is maintaining ageing infrastructure around the coast, where the capital cost of maintaining and improving that infrastructure is enormous.

We face a number of key challenges, the first of which relates to financial and funding constraints. The investment places a significant strain on those local authorities that have a large number of harbours and piers. That investment competes with other priorities within the councils and it makes it difficult to ensure that the appropriate investment is in place. Second, the infrastructure is deteriorating, as committee members will know, and it is suffering increasing damage due to more intense storms and the effects of climate change. Third, we have delivery challenges. We have very complex consent processes that we need to go through. These involve multiple agencies and lengthy timeframes. We have procurement challenges, supply chain constraints on marine grade materials and a very limited weather windows in which work can be carried out. There are also issues with timing in terms of getting work done during peak seasons. As the committee will understand, there is a change happening in the whole fishing area ,and there are now lots of other competing uses for our piers and harbours, be they leisure related, aquaculture or whatever. It can be difficult to manage those competing demands in our harbours and piers. We also have an issue with getting appropriate technical expertise and resources in place because there is a very limited pool of people with that kind of expertise.

We have a number of recommendations in our opening statement. The first is that there would be enhanced funding mechanisms giving multi-year certainty and flexibility for large projects. These would include advanced funding to plan, design and get the necessary consents for projects. Second, that there would be 100% funding for climate adaptation projects because it is important that we preserve this infrastructure for future generations. We also recommend 100% funding for large-scale dredging projects and that work be done to streamline the consent processes. A group in the Department of public expenditure is working to ensure that the various planning and marine consents operate together rather than one after the other. We further recommend that there would be strategic harbour classification to recognise the varying levels of national, regional and local harbours and that there would be integration with marine spatial planning to ensure that harbour development aligns with broader marine and coastal zone management objectives. Finally, we recommend the development of pontoons, including for impaired mobility access.

We are committed to working in partnership with the Government and our coastal communities to ensure that these vital assets are maintained, developed and climate-proofed for future generations. I look forward to members' questions.

I thank both witnesses for those summaries of their opening statements, which were circulated to members prior to the meeting. I will now open the floor for questions. I remind members that they have seven minutes and that this time is for both questions and responses.

I will start by repeating what I said at a previous meeting. No amount of harbour development will matter if fishers are forced to quit the industry because of the forthcoming cuts. That is vital, and I wanted to get that statement out there. Do the witnesses acknowledge that local authorities are struggling to maintain piers and harbours, with many not even aware that the Department has a marine section? Do they believe that a national audit of piers, harbours and slipways should be carried out, in light of this?

Deputy Ward and I come from a similar background, and I do recognise that we are struggling. All of the coastal communities and counties are struggling to maintain the infrastructure we have. We are trying to maintain an awful lot of infrastructure, and we are struggling. It is obviously more difficult and challenging now. Even though we have seen a serious decline in fishing, we still have to maintain the infrastructure. It has to be maintained to a standard whereby it is safe and can be used.

The funding required to maintain it a few decades ago was only a fraction of what is required today because of construction inflation and so on. All of the infrastructure is in complex locations. Any marine construction work is seriously complex, and it is extremely demanding to maintain what we have.

The Deputy mentioned a review of the entirety of the infrastructure. I would certainly suggest that some infrastructure would be identified as being crucial to the fishing industry. Obviously, we have our fishery harbour centres and all of the local authority harbours but maybe it is not necessary to maintain them all to the same standard. Certainly, we should be considering that some of them are in significant locations and require particular investment. We should consider a tiered structure, where we focus on certain fishery harbour centres and local authority fishery centres.

I ask departmental officials to outline the infrastructure projects it plans to fund in Killybegs that will support the fishing industry, as well as those not related to fishing given that the industry is currently in decline.

I am the chief engineer in the marine engineering division of the Department. We have a number of roles but primarily our role as regards the fishery harbour centres is to identify the projects that are crucial into the future. In Killybegs, there are two key projects which are nearing completion and should be completed by the end of this year. One is the Smooth Point project, which has been done on a phased basis over the past number of years. It has delivered over 120 m of additional berthage in the harbour. The other is the development of pontoon infrastructure, which is directed towards new business that seems to be developing in Killybegs involving leisure fishing, angling and the likes. Those facilities will also be used by local clubs, including the rowing club.

Going forward, there are major ambitions for Killybegs in relation to the southern pier extension. That is quite a large project. It is in its infancy in terms of our thought process. The previous Minister funded a cost-benefit analysis report on it. That was done on the basis of catches in 2023 and 2024 which may differ going into the future. It is in our plans, but like every plan that we have, it will be predicated on available funding. We work within an annual programme in the Department. Our budget is annual but certainly on the larger projects, we use what is called a contractual commitment system. If projects are started, they are the first projects that will be funded into the following year. They are the major projects in Killybegs. There are many other smaller issues that we deal with too. For every harbour, we have a safety and maintenance budget which is for things like maintaining ladders, bollards and so on but they are the major projects on our radar at the moment.
That is good. I would like to ask the CCMA whether it is true that funding which could have been allocated to infrastructural investment was not fully drawn down in the past.
I apologise, but I do not have that information to hand.
That is okay.
I will start with Mr. Clancy's final comment. First, what ongoing works in Killybegs are in the final stages?

Second, what is the justification for the southern pier extension at the moment? Mr. Clancy referred to it being based on landings for 2024-25. I wish those were the landings we could anticipate for 2025-26 but from what we are hearing, it does not look like that.

There is also the issue of foreshore licences. Whose responsibility is that? The foreshore licences take so long. Maybe it is rocket science, I do not know. However, I know from Burtonport that the ongoing works there are not necessarily being funded by marine, but by Deputy Calleary's Department. That is a combination of Arranmore and Burtonport. We have been told it is being looked at and will take some time. It is not that alone. Generally speaking, who should we be speaking to about trying to expedite? If the works are in the area of an SAC that takes longer again. We had the RNLI with us and there is an absolute necessity to carry out some emergency works. If it is an SAC, life is not important. Birds and bees in the SAC are more important. It is obviously not the witnesses' responsibility, but if we could be directed, we will invite those people in at a later stage, hopefully in the new year.

I have to admire my county of Donegal, which I am familiar with, and many other coastal counties. I do not think the local authorities there have ever refused grant aid on the basis of a local contribution. However, it is a bit difficult and is putting a lot of pressure on the local authorities. I know that Mr. Kehoe has referred to the 100% funding that will be required for some. We should be thinking of 100% funding for all infrastructure projects on the islands. What is the percentage? Is it the same, or is there flexibility there? We know some works were carried out in places last year, and it was 100% funding. I might be wrong, and I stand to be corrected, about a project in Donegal that was 100% funded. What is the general percentage required? Ms McSherry made a reference to the funding that would be spent this year. I think €4.3 million was announced by the Minister. I am not sure what that is. Will they send us a breakdown, not today but at a later stage? We do not expect them to have all the information here. Our Donegal friend who is now responsible for overall marine in Donegal might have got some assistance recently, and not before time. We should never forget, when we think of infrastructure works, that Roinn na Gaeltachta plays a part as well in providing funds. An application went in to it recently for assistance towards another marine engineer. We will be talking to the Minister, Deputy Calleary, with a view to approving that. Can we perhaps have answers to those few general questions?

I will take the Killybegs questions first, because the Deputy started with them. The key project we are finishing in Killybegs Fishery Harbour Centre this year is the Smooth Point project. It has been done over three phases. Phase 1 dealt with some contaminated material that had to be removed and treated. The second phase built the pier itself. It had a slightly troubled history because the contractor that started it got into financial difficulties, and we had to terminate that contract and engage another contractor to finish it. They finished the works. The section completing this year is a breasting dolphin. What we do in Killybegs with the larger refrigerated seawater, RSW, trawlers is berth them stern on. It gives far more room in the harbour when they are berthed stern on. However, because they are long and big vessels, they need a breasting dolphin to secure them at the bow. That breasting dolphin is complete. As for what we are completing between now and the end of the year, we want to be able to cold iron all the vessels in Killybegs.

It is already on the town pier. It essentially means they can plug into power and water. The vessels there are very large. They are pulling between 70 kVA and 80 kVA. It needs a major power infrastructure. As it has worked well on the town quay, we want to have it on the Smooth Point section too. A lot of the reason for that is there are large vessels - the Deputy probably is aware of it in Killybegs, that berth on what is known as the Blackrock pier. The Blackrock pier was never designed to accommodate the size of vessels that are there. We hope that, between the town pier and the Smooth Point pier that we will have adequate room to accommodate them. On the southern pier extension, the Deputy is right that the work we have done on that so far and any cost-benefit or economic analysis done, was done on the basis of fisheries. It was done on the basis of fisheries landing in 2023. We revised it upwards for 2024. We have not looked at 2025 yet, as we are in 2025, and yes, there is a concern about quotas going forward.

I will take the two questions on consenting and the local authority programme. With regard to consenting from the Minister for Agriculture, Food and the Marine, his authority under the Foreshore Act is confined to within the fishery harbour centres and aquaculture, as well as for specific projects with regard to fisheries. All other consenting in the marine space is a matter for the Marine Area Regulatory Authority, MARA. The Deputy asked where it sits. It sits with the Department of Climate, Energy and the Environment. The second question related to the breakdown of the €4.3 million local authority marine infrastructure scheme this year. We have that available and can pass it to the Deputy after the meeting, or we can send it through the clerk.
I thank Ms McSherry.

On the question of funding to the local authorities from the Department of Agriculture, Food and the Marine, the local authority marine infrastructure, LAMI, funding sent over the past two years was received at a rate of 95% versus 5% from the local authorities. We are grateful to the Department for making that change. When that scheme was originally announced it was 75% versus 25% but during the course of the scheme that was increased to 95%. The percentage of funding has since been reduced back to 75% versus 25% for the €4.33 million available this year. We also receive funding from the Department for rural regeneration. That funding is available to us, particularly for the islands. They are currently funding a pier in Galway for €35 million. I understand that is at 100% funding. That €35 million is just for an extension to a pier, and that is the scale of funding required to maintain our piers. That is at 100%. We still require further assistance because getting those projects shovel ready is onerous. For a local authority, having to fund that step of the project is an onerous and demanding task.
Did Mr. Sweeney say that last year the local contribution was reduced to 5% and this year going forward has gone up to 25%? Did he mention 95% and 75%? Maybe I got him wrong.

That was it exactly. Part of the LAMI funding received was at a rate of 95% versus 5% to the local authority. This year, it has gone back to the normal funding programme from the Department of agriculture, which was 75% versus 25%.
Maybe this is for the Department providing the money, but what was the justification to go from 75% to 95% and back again?
I thought that would have been a deterrent. Local authorities are under enough pressure without having to find that extra 20%.

The Brexit adjustment local authority marine infrastructure scheme, BALAMI, funding was for such an unprecedented amount compared to what local authorities had been used to previously, there would have been a difficulty providing matched funding for funding of this scale. If we look at our own county where the typical funding was €500,000 annually, that suddenly went to upwards of €10 million or €15 million. There was obviously going to be a massive contribution required by the council. We welcomed that decision taken at the time by the Department to increase the funding to 95%, leaving the local authority to provide 5%.

I have a couple of questions. We will then go Deputy Mac Lochlainn when he returns as he indicated that he wished to speak. My first set of questions is for the departmental officials. They relate to the requirement that projects, particularly those to improve local authority-owned ports and harbours, be shovel-ready. It does not seem to follow logic. The shovel-ready requirement seems to be an outlier when looking at schemes administered by other Departments where public money is provided on a shared basis to local authorities to conduct different projects. It does not include the preparatory work such as securing appropriate consent, planning permissions, environmental impact assessments and the rest of the licensing required to carry out works. Is that part of the scheme? Is it a diktat or a direction from the Department of public expenditure and reform? I discussed this with Minister of State, Deputy Dooley and I made the political ask that it would be changed. I do not expect the departmental officials to give a political answer. However, where do the underpinnings and criteria behind it originate from? They seem to be totally out of step with other funding models employed across the public service.

The local authority marine infrastructure scheme that we operate is a discretionary funding allocation within the Department. It is capital funding and therefore it must be assigned to capital works on an annual basis. We get our Vote on an annual basis and we have to manage within that. For projects to be shovel-ready, we open the scheme as early in the year as we can on receipt of the Vote and the allocation. We work with local authorities to ensure that they will get the scheme done by the end of the year because we cannot roll over that money. If it is not claimed in the year in hand, the money is lost to the local authority and the Vote. It does not get spent.

In terms of the preparatory work, that is all current spending and takes time. In order for us to ensure the most appropriate and efficient use of the moneys we have to allocate to local authority schemes, it must be ready to go. It must be done within the window and we must be able to pay within the window. That is the rationale behind it. These are capital moneys. They have to be engaged in capital works. It is a single budget. It is not a multi-annual budget. It must be ready to be initiated and completed within the calendar year. That includes us receiving all of the information from the local authority, conducting our due diligence and assurance checks and making those payments.

I understand. I thank Ms McSherry for her response. This may be more of a political point, but it is a false economy in many respects and it is a dysfunctional scheme. Earlier some of our witnesses described the frustration brought about by how difficult it is for local authorities to utilise this scheme. It limits what it can do. I have referred to Cé Heilbhic several times during this meeting. It is a really good example because Waterford City and County Council drew down significant funding over many years under that scheme for very important works, including new breakwater strengthening works and safety improvements. Excellent work has been done yet the fisheries harbour is not fit for purpose because of the lack of dredging. There is a dire need for that as lives and livelihoods are at risk.

The message I want to get across is that the system and the funding scheme need to be looked at again. The scheme ticks a number of boxes but it does not address the multitude of issues raised by fishermen and other users of ports and harbours.

I heard Ms McSherry say very clearly – I heard the Minister say it as well – that local authority-owned ports and harbours are not the responsibility of the Department. I challenge that in the sense that while they might not be under the ownership and control of the Department, certainly the provision and maintenance of safe fishing opportunities for the fishing fleet and the industry as a whole are within the purview of the Minister in particular. While he might not own the infrastructure, I would have thought the development and investment in same are a matter of serious responsibility for him.

In regard to Brexit and the Brexit adjustment reserve, I understand a little over €30 million of that fund was diverted into the local authority ports and harbours. It was a missed opportunity that it was simply plugged into the existing methodology that we have just discussed for disbursing those funds. That meant lots of the long-standing works that were required to take place, for which there was a significant demand, could not fit into it. There was a huge windfall. Extra money was put into the scheme over two years and it could not be availed of by the likes of Waterford City and County Council or other local authorities for the work they thought really needed to be done. I understand €213 million was handed back to the European Commission. How much of the €30 million that was specifically earmarked for local authority ports and harbours was handed back?

The initial allocation was €35 million and that increased to €55.3 million. Over that two-year period, I believe €40.4 million was drawn down, inclusive of VAT. The key issue to reflect on is the Brexit adjustment reserve had very particular terms and conditions and timelines. All the moneys had to be spent by the end of 2023. There was no provision within the regulation to spend beyond that. The Department worked very closely with the local authorities to maximise the drawdown. However, we did have to ensure that the project could be commenced and finished in order to draw the money back from the EU. Over that two-year period, €55.3 million was made available to the local authorities. Mr. Sweeney spoke about the fact that we raised the co-funding amount from 75%, which is the standard over the years for the local authority marine infrastructure scheme, to 95%. That was to enable local authorities to draw down as much as they possibly could. Many of them had consents in place. We were able to process many of the consents quickly. However, as Deputy Gallagher mentioned, one has to go through the assessment process and meet all the environmental requirements in order to gain a consent. The local authorities were faced with that time challenge as well.

In terms of handing money back, the Brexit adjustment reserve was an amount of money we could draw down from for schemes. The Department of public expenditure – I cannot remember the full title – managed the scheme on an overall basis within the Exchequer and we drew down from the scheme. For all the schemes that we had, we maximised the amount that we felt we could realistically draw down and that our stakeholders were in a position to draw down and finalise.
To go back to the point the Chair makes, there was a very finite cut-off point for the time that we could utilise that funding.
I thank Ms McSherry. To confirm, there was €55.3 million in total from the BAR allocated to local authority ports and harbours and €40.4 million was spent. A little under €15 million went unspent.

The issue with a lot of the local authorities that were seeking to make applications was not the time constraint but the money constraint. It was having money upfront to tender for and carry out all the work required to get consents, licences and all the rest. There is a huge level of disappointment across the board within local authorities.

They might not say it outright but, when speaking to engineers, I can see that there is a level of disappointment that the opportunity was not taken and the money, while it was not physically sent back, was not availed of to do the works that needed to be done.
Could I clarify one point?
Yes.
Stage payment processes were made available to local authorities to enable them to manage their cash flow.
Was that for preparatory work such as the licensing and surveying work?

To go back to the original point, the Cathaoirleach's question was if we handed back money. The issue is that we did not draw down the money. We did not have a pot of money, so we did not hand it back. It was available for us to draw down.

On the Cathaoirleach's point that he felt the 5% co-funding was a strain on local authorities, stage payment processes were put in place for local authorities in order to enable them manage their cash flow.

What I am trying to establish is whether Ms McSherry is telling me that there was a facility where credit of some kind or staged payments was available to local authorities to carry out the preparatory work, specifically licensing and survey work. That is where the issue lies, in particular with the case I am talking about in Cé Helvick, but in lots of other cases as well, because the preparatory work costs far in excess of the actual dredging or other work that takes place. Therein lies the problem with this scheme. That is the nub of the issue.
This is a capital scheme and those preparatory works are current. I know that might sound-----
Jesuitical.
-----discrete, but they are the rails within which we operate in terms of funding.

I understand that. I am veering into the political now. I do not wish the witnesses to offer a political opinion or anything like that but my political sense of it is that the scheme needs to be reformed, as it is dysfunctional and it is not fit for purpose for those precise reasons.

I have run out of time. I am not good at chairing myself. I thank the local government sector and our three witnesses in particular for their really comprehensive statement. I concur with all the points they make in it. Multi-annual funding is crucially important. Recognising the lack of in-house expertise and technical knowledge within the local authority sector is an important detail. Some of the witnesses we had in the first part of the meeting made the point that there could be some kind of a shared services system that is already a tried and tested model in the local government sector, but for marine infrastructure. Is a shared services model for managing that expertise and knowledge something the witnesses have discussed or would be interested in pursuing?
It is not one that has been discussed so far but it is something we will bring back and see if it might work. I will talk to my colleagues in the coastal authorities about that at committee level.
County Meath, famously, does not have a long coastline.
I will be a bit Donegal for a moment and acknowledge Mr. Sweeney. I thank him for the excellent job he does with the resources and challenges he has. He is respected by the communities he works with.

The presentation from the local authority County and City Management Association is excellent in understanding the challenges. The vast majority of the State's piers and harbours are under the control of local authorities.

I ask that the presentations from IIMRO and NIFA, the organisations representing inshore fishermen and island fishermen, be circulated to the local authority witnesses and to the Department. There clearly is significant room for improvement in terms of a basic safety audit of all piers and harbours. One of the persons who attended the initial session showed me a photograph of a pier submerged in water. A fisherman would have to swim out to get to his boat.

A tiny minority, of course, would be that serious but we all know of issues with cranes, lifts and ladders. People should be able to come safely off their boat and lift their fish onto the pier or harbour across the State. I want to get the views of both the Department and the CCMA on an audit of all piers and harbours to get a sense of where we are at - the big picture from up in the helicopter - and a full sense of what is going on out there, and then to have a national programme to address this. I would like to get the witnesses' feedback on that.

I can address that. I will speak from a Galway perspective in terms of my experience and knowledge. We had a significant audit carried out probably 20 years ago at this stage. We updated that recently. We have a pretty good handle on all of our piers and harbours and the condition and status of those piers and harbours. I would refer back to what Mr. Sweeney said earlier about maybe tiering the piers and harbours within the local authorities from a funding perspective. There are piers that might not be in great condition but are very lightly used, maybe with little or no fishing from them, whereas other ones are in need of significant investment. The funding mechanism is the same irrespective. Some of the larger piers would benefit from a strategic look, given the larger piers and harbours would need funding in excess of the limits that are on the BALAMI scheme, whereas for other ones, the BALAMI scheme is appropriate. In answer to the Deputy's question, a national audit would be helpful. It is always good to have a comprehensive audit. However, I would not see that as being something that is the major deficit. I think-----

Why? If there is a pier where a fisherman would have to swim out - by the way, I am not suggesting this is in Galway; Mr. Prendergast cannot speak with authority for the entire State - then why would a comprehensive audit of all piers and harbours across the State under the auspices of the Department not help?

There is no reason it would not help. Of course, it would be beneficial, but I think we have a reasonably good handle on the issues that are there. That is not to say our piers and harbours do not need significant investment; they do. An audit may help. It will add to the information base that we have. However, that information base is not necessarily problematic from the experience I have. That would be my view. Obviously, however, if there was investment in a national audit, which would give us a better and more up-to-date picture, then we would certainly avail of that and see that as being beneficial.

Similarly, the second-last audit that was carried out in Donegal was in 1999. That was from an economic perspective and it looked at the 153 piers and harbours throughout the county. It was a very detailed report. It talked about the economic investment, what works and where development-wise we are required to bring them up to standard.

I in 2017 and 2018, we carried out a safety review of all of our piers and harbours. That identified a number of the types of issues the Deputy just mentioned. It made a whole list of recommendations and we followed up with those recommendations. We drew down capital funding to carry out measures that were identified in that review. That was in 2018. Since that, and before that as well, what we rely on are just visual inspections carried out periodically by our outdoor staff, harbourmasters, engineers and so on. As the Deputy will be aware as well, we have the communication with most of our harbour users. They all have an open line to us. As soon as defects are identified, they are raised and brought to our attention. We do get to them fairly quickly, particularly where there are safety concerns.

Would a national audit be of benefit? Yes, it certainly would. It would be even from an economic perspective as well as from a safety point of view to identify those harbours that need particular attention - for example, in the Deputy's own locality in Greencastle and Glengad - where there is a large amount of fishing activity and where they need substantial investment. Therefore, yes, I do agree.

In terms of the Department's response to the proposal for a national audit, to be clear, I am not talking about a huge amount of money spent on economic appraisals and all that. I am talking about basic health and safety audits to make sure the piers and harbours are workable for people.

One thing that infuriates me is the issue of dredging of piers and harbours and the absolute bureaucracy people have to go through. It is just shocking. This is the basic safe maintenance of a pier or harbour. Until recent times, two or three Departments were involved in the process. It was the Department with responsibility for planning, the Department of Agriculture, Food and the Marine and possibly the Department of the environment and climate too. I just want to get a sense of the Departments involved. Obviously, the Maritime Area Regulatory Authority, MARA, now is in play in having to deal with this. How do we fast-track permission to dredge a pier or harbour so people can access it and leave it safely?
Those are two questions then on a national audit and the whole issue of how we can tidy up the bureaucracy and give people permission to keep these places safe.

I will take the second one first. As the Department and the operators of the fishery harbour centres, we are subject to the same consenting requirements to dredge as every other party in the country who wishes to dredge. The length of time is a source of frustration for us. I will ask Mr. Clancy to perhaps speak a little more to the experience we have had, particularly in Howth, and the impact it has had on our ability to get consent to dredge.
The second question was about an audit of local authority-owned piers and harbours. To be frank, Minister, the local authority-owned piers and harbours-----
I was enjoying that for a second.
Carry on.
I apologise, Deputy.
That is no problem.

To be frank, this Department does not own those piers and harbours and it would be remiss of me to suggest that we would engage in an audit of them. What we do respond to on an annual basis are the requests from the local authorities. The Deputy mentioned specifically cranes, lifts and ladders. They are things that we fund. When we go out with the scheme on an annual basis, the local authorities have done their assessments and made the prioritisations, and they submit their projects in a prioritised fashion. Then, we allocate the funding that is available to us. We are not guaranteed funding every year. We are not guaranteed the same level of funding every year. However, we are in a position to aid those local authorities. The prioritisation and identification of those needs are a matter for the local authority. Sometimes we are in a position. Mr. Sweeney spoke to the BALAMI scheme and Donegal. Donegal was obviously very badly impacted by Brexit. However, we were able to assist Donegal and fund them to the tune of €25 million over two years. That has made a significant impact on those piers and harbours there, but we do not have that opportunity of the Brexit adjustment reserve fund every year.
I will ask Mr. Clancy to take the Deputy through the dredging challenge.

Howth would be our case in point as regards the dredging experience and so forth. Any fishermen who use Howth have had a problem, particularly going into the trawler base now over the last number of years. The harbourmaster is restricting the size of vessels coming in there. I recognise that the committee had representatives from the RNLI at the previous session. Howth is one of their bases and we have a problem maintaining a clear exit from the harbour for them as well. On where the dredging is Howth is at, it is approximately three, going on four, years since we started on what I would call the dredging journey. We applied for planning permission to dredge the material and then rather than export it all to Sutton to a tip or whatever, our plan was to reuse it and extend the pier, which we felt was the more climate-friendly solution.

On the planning application, we were successful in getting planning but it was appealed and it went to the board, as it was at the time. We got planning permission from An Bord Pleanála in August 2024 but to reuse the material, we need a waste licence from the EPA. It speaks to what the Deputy is talking about that the EPA cannot really consider that until the planning is in place and that kicks off another process. We are waiting for the outcome of that waste licence and then we will be starting. It is three or four years in a process in a harbour that is severely restricted at the moment and possibly approaching health and safety issues with the RNLI. It is a concern we would share. I am not sure it is within my remit to deal with it but I would welcome if anything could be done with it.

If I may add something to that, the Deputy asked was there a process under way to try and streamline and enhance it. It is something that we have contributed to. There is a project under way with the Department of Public Expenditure, Infrastructure, Public Service Reform and Digitalisation, which is looking at infrastructure consents and trying to streamline those. We would have fed in our own feedback. Mr. Clancy's work involves a large amount of civil engineering and he is au fait with the process. We would have brought to their attention some of our experiences and some of the thoughts we had on how to resolve those. That is ongoing work with the Department of Public Expenditure, Infrastructure, Public Service Reform and Digitalisation.
I thank Ms McSherry.

Sin deireadh ár gcruinniú. Everybody who indicated has had an opportunity to speak. That brings us to a conclusion in terms of the discussion for this meeting. I thank all our witnesses for being here, for their contributions and for answering our questions forthrightly. I thank the members, as always, for their conduct in the meeting and for their contributions as well.

With all that said, the meeting stands adjourned. As a reminder for those who joined us a little later, we are meeting tomorrow in private session at 11 a.m. via Microsoft Teams as we have a lot of housekeeping to do.
